narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: This study on autism and social communication will generate multi-modal datasets from youth participants, including demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral and cognitive assessments, neuroimaging and/or physiological measures, derived variables, and associated documentation. The estimated volume of data is substantial, with neurobiological data representing the largest portion of storage.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected data types will be preserved and shared to facilitate secondary research use, promote transparency, and enhance reproducibility. This decision aligns with NIH's commitment to maximizing the sharing of scientific data while protecting participant privacy and confidentiality. Broad data sharing consent/assent has been obtained from participants as appropriate.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following will be made accessible: 
A comprehensive data dictionary defining all variables
Study protocols outlining data collection procedures
Data collection instruments used in the research
README files providing context for each dataset

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools and software are needed to access or manipulate shared scientific data. Specifically:
For neuroimaging data, FMRIB Software Library (FSL) and FreeSurfer will be utilized.
For statistical analyses, R programming language with relevant packages will be employed.
These tools can be accessed through their respective official websites, ensuring that other researchers can use them to analyze and build upon the shared data.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied. The project will adhere to the National Institute of Mental Health Data Archive (NDA) guidelines for data submission, incorporating NDA GUID elements into the dataset structure. Additionally, data dictionaries will follow standardized formats to ensure clarity and consistency across different datasets.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the National Institute of Mental Health Data Archive (NDA), a repository designated by NIH for storing and sharing research data related to mental health studies.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: Each dataset will be assigned a persistent unique identifier, ensuring that it can be easily located and accessed. Standard indexing tools compatible with the NDA's data discovery interface will also be utilized to enhance findability.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of publication of the main findings or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. Data will remain accessible for a minimum of 10 years after the project's completion to allow for extensive secondary analysis and replication studies.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While maximizing data sharing is a priority, certain limitations apply due to the need to protect participant privacy and confidentiality. Data will be de-identified before sharing, and access may require approval from the NDA to ensure that data use aligns with the consent provided by participants.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Yes, access to the scientific data will be controlled through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). Researchers seeking to access the data must apply through the NDA's mechanisms, which include obtaining approval based on their intended use of the data and adherence to terms of use that protect participant confidentiality.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants:
All shared data will be thoroughly de-identified.
Certificates of Confidentiality will be obtained where applicable to further safeguard against disclosure.
Researchers accessing the data must agree to terms of use that include respecting participant confidentiality.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigators (PIs), in collaboration with the institutional review board (IRB) and other relevant bodies at our institution. The PIs are responsible for ensuring that data management practices adhere to the plan, including timely submission of data to the designated repository, maintenance of documentation, and oversight of access requests. Regular reviews will be conducted annually or upon significant project milestones to ensure ongoing compliance with NIH policies and the terms outlined in this plan.
